section.title: What can I do with FlyMine?

listitem.para: Browse data. All entries in FlyMine have a summary page includes data from all aspects. Some example gene: ..... and protein pages..... Enter any identifier or symbol in the Quick Search box to get started. [tutorial 1]

Template Queries. FlyMine has a powerful query interface that can run arbitrary queries on the integrated database. A library of pre-defined ('template') queries that simply require filling in a form is available. Find lists of templates on each aspect page or using the Template Search box below. [tutorial 2].

Design your own query. Advanced users can use a flexible query interface to construct their own queries. You can save queries you have created for future use and create your own templates. See the user manual and tutorials for more information.

section.para: FlyMine is updated regularly, adding new data, tools and user interface features. For an idea of what is coming up see the [roadmap]. If there is any data you would like to see added to FlyMine please contact us.

section.title: More about FlyMine
section.para: FlyMine is an integrated web-based database of genomic, expression and proteomics data for Drosophila, Anopheles and other insects, built to complement existing resources such as FlyBase. With the completion of increasing numbers of genome sequences has come an explosion in the development of both computational and experimental high-throughput techniques for deciphering the functions of molecules and their interactions. These techniques include theoretical methods for deducing function such as analysis of protein homologies, structural domain predictions, phylogenetic profiling and protein domain fusions and empirical methods such as microarray gene expression studies, two-hybrid protein-protein interaction experiments, protein co-immunoprecipitation and large-scale RNAi screens. The result is a huge amount of data, and the challenge is to extract meaningful knowledge and patterns of biological significance that can lead to new experimentally testable hypotheses. Many of these high-throughput data-sets, however, are noisy and the data quality can vary significantly. While for certain objectives each of these techniques is useful in its own right, stronger inferences can be made if one is able to combine data from different sources. Currently biological data are stored in a wide variety of formats in numerous different places, making such complex queries across these data sources hard. One of the current challenges for bioinformatics is therefore to develop resources for the integration and combined analysis of such data.

The FlyMine database is built using InterMine, which was developed as an integral part of the FlyMine project. InterMine is an open-source data warehouse system for integrating data from many sources into one object-based database. The FlyMine data model is generated by merging existing and emerging ontologies and standards (e.g. MAGE, SO, PSI), thus enabling data to be loaded from a variety of sources and providing the flexibility to easily incorporate new data sources as they appear. A powerful and flexible query interface to these data enables users to perform arbitrary and complex queries across the data either via a web interface or a programming interface. The web interface enables users to build queries, by combining classes of objects and applying constraints to their attributes. Queries and sets of results can be saved for use in further queries or for feeding to analysis programs. The result display includes links to external databases, class and attribute browsing capability as well as the ability to select data for download in a variety of formats. In addition, a number of predefined template queries and a browse utility provide easier and more direct access to the data. Genome sequence features can be viewed with the integrated GBrowse genome viewer and protein structures can be viewed and analysed with the JMol Java applet. Additional display and analysis tools will be available soon. Help is available through query examples, tutorials, on-line help pages and an analysis support help-desk.

The first release of FlyMine includes genome annotation data for Drosophila melanogaster and Anopheles gambiae, yeast 2-hybrid data for D. melanogaster and C. elegans, and orthologue/ paralogue data relating the genes of these organisms. The inclusion of Caenorhabditis elegans orthologues also gives access to C. elegans RNAi phenotypes. 3-D strcutural domain predictions for several D. melanogaster proteins are also included. Development of the database is currently rapid. We aim to add new functional genomics data sources and increase coverage to further insects as data become available, as well as maintaining continued development of the web interface and analysis tools. We hope that FlyMine will become a valuable data mining tool for the insect genomics community.
